Senior
Nutrition: Switch to a senior dog diet to accommodate changing nutritional needs. 
Health Monitoring: Increase vet visits to twice a year for thorough check-ups. 
Exercise: Adjust exercise routines to be gentler on aging joints, but still provide mental stimulation. 
Comfort: Provide comfortable bedding and accommodations to support aging joints and muscles. 
Watch for Signs of Aging: Keep an eye out for signs of cognitive decline, arthritis, or other age-related issues. 

Geriatric
Increased Health Concerns: They are more prone to age-related health issues such as arthritis, cognitive decline, organ dysfunction, and sensory impairments, necessitating more comprehensive health care. 
Regular Veterinary Check-ups: They require more frequent vet visits, typically every six months, compared to younger dogs, to monitor their health closely and detect and manage any emerging issues promptly. 
Nutrition and Weight Management: They have different nutritional needs compared to younger dogs, requiring adjustments to their diet to support aging bodies and prevent obesity or malnutrition. 
Pain Management and Mobility Support: They are more likely to experience pain, stiffness, and mobility issues, necessitating specific strategies for pain management and mobility support, such as medication, supplements, and environmental modifications. 
Mental Stimulation and Quality of Life: As dogs age, maintaining mental stimulation and overall quality of life becomes increasingly important to slow cognitive decline and ensure their well-being in their later years.
